Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Geochemical variation of the Pacific crust subducting beneath the Izu-Bonin arc and its implications for the generation of arc magmas
Award.AbstractNarration: The Izu-Bonin arc in the western Pacific Ocean is one of the best-investigated volcanic arcs in the world and lead (Pb) isotopes are one of the foremost isotopic tracers of the recycling of altered ocean crust. It is widely accepted that there is a strong compositional link between magmas erupted along volcanic arcs above subduction zones and subducted altered oceanic crust that is cycling back down into the mantle via deep ocean trenches. That said, currently available Pb elemental and isotopic data for Izu-Bonin arc magmas and the associated subducting altered ocean crust are at odds with this model, raising the spector that altered ocean crust may not, in fact, be an important source of arc magmas, which throws into question our understanding of arc magmatism as a whole. This research will use geochemical analyses (elemental and isotopic) of new and already collected samples of ocean crust to determine whether there is a discrepancy between subduction zone input and arc output in the Izu-Bonin arc-trench system. Using a UNOLS ship, samples of basaltic crust will be dredged from the seafloor along a ~900 km transect targeting active, vertical fault scarps along the Pacific Plate which is subducting into the Izu-Bonin Trench. This transect allows sampling of rocks of a range of crustal ages, which will include samples from the area where there is a hypothesized change in the composition of Mesozoic Pacific crust at ~125 Ma. Samples will be analyzed for chemical composition and the results will be used to determine mass balances of slab input/arc output. The work will also entail a calibration of the magnetic timescale. Results of the investigation will provide a crucial test of current concepts on crustal recycling at subduction zones and modes of crustal extraction from the mantle in which the subduction processing of carbon plays a pivotal role. Goals of this research are linked directly to the science plan of the NSF-funded Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) and will provide essential data input to four upcoming IODP drilling expeditions (three JOIDES Resolution legs scheduled for 2014 and one CHIKYU expedition that is pending). Broader impacts of the project will foster national and international collaboration among the investigators and will support two investigators from groups under-represented in the sciences. The project also will support graduate and undergraduate students who will be fully integrated into the science discovery aspect of the project. Project results will be incorporated into a 1-day workshop for teachers from the San Diego Unified School District through the NSF-funded Center for Ocean Science Education Excellence in California.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative research: Geochemical variation of the Pacific crust subducting beneath the Izu-Bonin arc: Implications for the generation of arc magmas

The main objectives of this project were to test 1) if the composition of the Pacific oceanic crust on the east side of, and subducting westward into, the almost north-south trending Izu-Bonin Trench is variable, and 2) if such variability is the source of the systematic north-south compositional variation of lavas erupted from the Izu-Bonin volcanoes located above the subduction zone, on the west side of the trench. It is generally accepted that the distinct compositional features of volcanic lavas above subduction zones in the oceanic environment come from two major sources, the subducting oceanic plate and the mantle sandwiched between the subducting plate and the overriding plate above the subduction zone. Moreover, the subducting oceanic plate consists, from top to bottom, of sediment, variably altered oceanic crust (AOC) and lithospheric mantle. Compared to the lithospheric mantle, AOC and especially sediment contain many of the trace elements that are enriched in the volcanic lavas and, thus, are considered the primary sources of the compositional signature of subduction zone lavas. In the Izu-Bonin subduction system, the volcanic lavas exhibit a distinct latitudinal variation in their composition especially in Pb isotopic ratios. The Pb isotopic ratios of Izu-Bonin lavas in the southern sector of the system are similar to those of Pacific oceanic crust whereas those of lavas in the northern sector are similar to those of Indian oceanic crust. Notably, the sediment on top of the oceanic plate subducting into the Izu-Bonin Trench is relatively and uniformly thin (about 400 meters) as well as compositionally quite homogeneous. Thus, it had been hypothesized that the north-south compositional variation observed in Izu-Bonin volcanic lavas comes directly from the subducting AOC that possesses a Pacific oceanic crust-type Pb isotopic ratios in the south and an Indian oceanic crust-type Pb isotopic ratios in the north.  

This project was primarily to test the aforementioned hypothesis through a field sampling program and a laboratory analytic program. The field program was carried out using the R/V Roger Revelle of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography during the RR1412 cruise to the Izu-Bonin Trench in October-November 2016. During the cruise, AOC samples were successfully collected by dredging along a north-south transect from the subducting oceanic plate. The analytic program, consisting of major plus trace element and Sr-Nd-Pb-Hf isotope analyses of representative AOC samples, was also successfully accomplished. Results of the project comprise two chapters in the Ph.D. dissertation of Kathryn Durkin, a graduate student at Scripps who was heavily involved in both the field and laboratory programs. The main conclusion in the first chapter is that the subducting AOC is not compositionally homogeneous; those from the northern section of the subducting plate are relatively more geochemically enriched than those from the southern section. Significantly, the southern AOC samples indeed have the Pacific oceanic crust-type Pb isotopic ratios, quite similar to those of the southern Izu-Bonin volcanic lavas, but although the isotopic ratios of the northern AOC samples are different from the southern AOC samples, they do not posses Indian oceanic crust-type Pb isotopic ratios. Thus, results indicate that the currently subducting AOC is not the source of the latitudinal compositional variation of Izu-Bonin volcanic lavas. Instead, an inherent compositional variation of the mantle source is most likely the source of the compositional variation of volcanic lavas.

The second chapter focused on the origin of the compositional variation of the subducting oceanic crust. From magnetic anomaly signals on the seafloor, the age of the subducting oceanic crust ranges from roughly 120 million years ago in the north to roughly 145 million years ago in the south. Results indicate that the latitudinal compositional variation of the oceanic crust resulted from a change in the composition of its upper mantle source at roughly 125 million years ago, almost simultaneously with the formation of the Mesozoic large igneous provinces in the Pacific. Pacific oceanic crust generated before ~125 million years ago is simply similar in composition to normal Pacific oceanic crust whereas oceanic crust generated after ~125 million years ago is geochemically more enriched, roughly overlapping in composition to some of the Mesozoic large igneous provinces in the Pacific. Thus, results indicate that a large section of the Pacific upper mantle was contaminated by an enriched mantle source, most likely coming from several plumes or a superplume that formed the Mid-Cretaceous large igneous provinces in the Pacific at roughly 125 million years ago.
